/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I think rdo jobs broken with  https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1961056
isn't there a lot of history here? hasn't it been 10s for years? why would we now need 30s. I just want to make sure there isn't an underlying cause that needs to be addressed.

The only history I know is where we increased the client/server timeout without increasing the check timeout https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/commit/1bee7bc8fa0ca5ace330e54bc3e64d7f6692d5a7.

We don't prioritize healthcheck requests over normal requests. Therefore, if there are more requests than the number of workers and those requests take more than 10 seconds for the backend to process, check requests would timeout and haproxy would mark the services unavailable.

Below[1] is the traceback from haproxy. GET /v2.1/servers/* requests take 14+s on an average (probably because that involves requests to nova, placement, ironic and what not, there is probably some performance regression here) and then all healthcheck requests fail and the service has been marked unhealthy.

If we bump timeout for requests to be processed within 2m or more by the backend, we also need to bump check timeout. We may get away by increasing number worker threads to more than the number of concurrent requests, but that's not a practical solution.

Also, there is a trade-off with setting an agressive check timeout, with load backend servers get slower, the healthchecks are delayed... until suddenly they all timeout together, HAProxy thinks ALL servers died at once and the entire service goes down.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Replacement for the prior patch, Also after a little discussion with Dmitry. I think behavior wise this a) short circuits the fallback by making it forever impossible if session auth has occured. This raises an exception to the caller which I believe is appropriate. And it also b) prevents a transient failure after we've reset primary values to determine *if* we can reset authentication from causing us to fall back to basic authentication.

This is fixing issue with previous patch that fell back to BasicAuth all the time (now it creates Sessions again), but there are new issues.

Checking this workflow:
1) Initiate sushy
2) Delete session on BMC to mimic failures
3) Continue using sushy

The outcome with old/master sushy:
- Session gets re-created on BMC, sushy continues to work

The outcome with this patch:
- Session fails to recreate, it gets into some kind of never ending recursion that ends with "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object"

Inline I'm leaving a suggestion about direction to go. Current patch builds on top of solution that has turned out to be already problematic and adds more complexity to it.

Thanks for the full backtrace! What I thought, but I wanted to make sure.

I do kind of agree, adding more complexity is a problem and I don't think we *can* fix everything, but there are distinct failure cases we've got here which may not really work without some complexity. We've got some code like that in python-ironicclient where we get to handle some "odd" cases. I mean, who would have thought entire clusters might have issues of loosing connectivity sporadically to the BMCs enough that the client gets locked out and becomes useless.

what if.. it's not possible to fix current solution by adding more stuff/complexity to it, because the current solution is "bug" itself/it conflicts with legit workflow? :)

sushy/connector.py.message:
theoretically, this URL could be differently named. Practically, don't know if vendors going this route. That is, this URL can be whatever is in the root /Links/Sessions/@odata.id and in SessionService's Sessions/@odata.id. In sushy that corresponds to `Sushy.get_sessions_path()` and `SessionService._get_sessions_collection_path()`.
So far there was '/Sessions' hardcoded only as a fallback if two above fail [1][2][3]. If vendors choose to have something else in @odata.id, then this check will not work.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/6af4ba929f64fef4e070af1b0accc920fdfbec73/sushy/auth.py#L154
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/6af4ba929f64fef4e070af1b0accc920fdfbec73/sushy/resources/sessionservice/sessionservice.py#L113
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/6af4ba929f64fef4e070af1b0accc920fdfbec73/sushy/resources/sessionservice/sessionservice.py#L116

deliverables/wallaby/os-brick.yaml.message:
Hmm, there is a change that has some default config change [1] if I understand correctly. If that is true, then this is not fortunate to release on stable branches. Especially not with a PATCH version bump :S (Though there is no other option as 4.4.0 is used in xena)

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/7a7db2589be847ccb6f5bee32975875c/log/tox/list-changes-results.log#1500-1503

Thanks @Brian for the explanation. So this kind of need an exception from stable policy then as I understand. Which is OK to me, if cinder team is also OK with it. 
(About the prelude: maybe the Upgrade Notes are enough, no need for a prelude).
And by the way, sorry for not commenting these to the first release patch (stable/xena).

Maybe one thing:
@Sean if you are around: could you please review this patch from Cinder / stable-maint-core / and release manager perspectives as well? o: )

Yeah, I don't know what to do about this one.  We aren't changing the default value, but by switching to file locks, the default value is no longer appropriate (which I guess sort of amounts to the same thing as changing the default?).  The problem is that there isn't a sensible default value for this option:

  # Directory to use for lock files.  For security, the specified directory
  # should only be writable by the user running the processes that need locking.
  # Defaults to environment variable OSLO_LOCK_PATH. If external locks are used,
  # a lock path must be set. (string value)
  #lock_path = <None>

And you're right that only being able to use a patch version bump is a problem.  At least it shows up right at the top of the release notes:

https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/os-brick/wallaby.html

The only other thing I can think of is that we could add a prelude to the release notes (though it would say, "Make sure you read the Upgrade Notes").

Thanks Sean and Elod.  Here's the situation.

The instructions:
"In the [oslo_concurrency] section, configure the lock path:"
occur in these installation guides:

Nova: Install and configure a controller node
Nova: Install and configure a compute node
Cinder: Install and configure controller node
Cinder: Install and configure a storage node

... back through at least Pike (all branches before pike have been deleted from os-brick so we can't possibly backport this change farther than that).  So anyone following the instructions will have a value set for this option, which is used for some other functionality (not just this particular change). Hence it's unlikely that anyone will be running os-brick in an environment where lock_path isn't already set.

So to answer Jeremy's question from the release team meeting, the impact to someone who hasn't hit the bug addressed by this backported fix *and* who doesn't read the release notes should be basically no impact because they've already been setting that option for other functionality.
Thanks for checking the things thoroughly and for sharing the details here. Considering all these I'm OK to +2 the patch!

I think the good thing here is most deployers will probably not need to care about this setting. It's only an issue when running nova and cinder services on the same node, which even then folks can do without setting this and things will work *most* of the time. At least that's what I remember of it.

Normally we would not want to make a change like this on a stable branch. But sometimes changes are necessary to address real world needs, so there's certainly been precedence for making exceptions with things like this. So my take is, while not ideal, this should be an OK change to make. Especially with it included in the release notes. It would be great if we could bump the minor release version, but this should be OK as 4.3.3.

Thanks for sharing your view on this Sean! This is a good input for the cinder team as well, i think, to re-evaluate this (as discussed with Brian on last release meeting [1]).

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/releaseteam/2022/releaseteam.2022-02-25-14.00.log.html#l-205

container_config_scripts/nova_libvirt_in.message: Need to do this before merging
yeah, I can confirm that within the containers you always have /etc/ceph: CephConfigPath (on the host) is always mapped into /etc/ceph in containers (for nova, cinder, glance, manila, etc).

CephConfigPath is passed to the THT that calls this script:

  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/nova/nova-modular-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L91-L95

That THT then mounts wherever CephConfigPath is set to is mounted into /etc/ceph on the nova container

  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/nova/nova-modular-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L719-L730

The nova contianer is called with CLUSTER:USER:

  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/nova/nova-modular-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L731-L739

But using /etc/ceph should be correct as that's the path inside the container.

{% if enable_ironic_ipxe | bool %}
{# NOTE(mgoddard): iPXE uses the TFTP image cache (tftp_master_path, default
   /tftpboot/master_images), in which images get hard linked to the http_root
   directory (/httpboot). These must be on the same device, but /httpboot and
   /tftpboot live in separate Docker volumes. Override the default paths for
   iPXE to place them both in /httpboot. This prevents mixing PXE and iPXE. #}
tftp_root = /httpboot
tftp_master_path = /httpboot/master_images
tftp_server = {{ api_interface_address }}
{% endif %}

This workarounds PEP8 failing in neutronclient/client.py:
193	            if self.auth_token is None:
194	                self.auth_token = ""

A MITM could both replace the key and then serve pkgs signed with the replaced key, so this is in fact a valid concern IMO.

extrepo has the key built into its data, so that makes an attack much more difficult: https://salsa.debian.org/extrepo-team/extrepo-data/-/blob/master/repos/debian/osbpo.yaml

zigo is working on making extrepo have a builtin copy of that data, so as to avoid the dependency on salsa being reachable, I think that that is the better solution. The other way to fix the issue would be to place the key itself into kolla.

it seems the reason we used it is that we need gnupg key delivered securely - maybe we could just embed it in kolla if we can't get osbpo to serve https (though tbh it's lame it does not support https in 2022)

The problem is that this doesn't mean that no network will be attached to the container; actually, what happens is that Docker attaches the none Docker network [1] to the container (the default Docker networks have confusing names). If you inspect the container, you'll see none listed there as a network, and the veth pair is created just as when using the bridge Docker network. The only real difference is that the none Docker network is completely isolated (can't be pinged from the host nor from other containers).

I've decided to disconnect all Docker networks from the just created container, so that listing Docker networks attached to it and its veth pairs is always predictable, and we don't need to filter out the bridge or none Docker networks in methods further below (i.e., get_container_networks and get_container_veths).

With that in mind, I think it doesn't really matter if we disconnect the bridge or the none Docker networks, so I just left bridge there and disconnected it right after.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/network/none/

question: do you need to always create a new docker network? Or it just make easier to get veth information from bridges? Maybe would be good to clarify that with some comments for future devs that may want to change this code.
Thanks Eduardo

Yes, for both questions. In Docker, if we want to add a new interface to the container, we need to connect a new Docker network to it, so that a new bridge and a new veth pair are created and plugged into the container. This also makes it easier to retrieve bridge and veth information from the containers, because we know that for every subnet present in a given share server, there'll be one Docker network, one bridge, and one veth pair, so getting and manipulating this data is very straightforward. But I agree, that's not obvious at a first glance, so I can add a comment explaining the procedure in a follow-up change.

I think the current failure is due to trying to use owner on the synchronize module. It works for file and template but not synchronize in the same way. With synchronize it is meant to be a boolean that determines if we should preserve the owner from the host side. In this case I think we should just drop owner and group and keep the old behavior. The previous failure should've been a hint that I would catch. This is failing now because we're writing out the docker-compose.yaml file as if it were a template with variables to substitute but the synchronize module doesn't expand templates.

Instead we should replace this block with a template block. Something like:

  - name: Make docker-compose dir
    file:
      state: directory
      path: /etc/registry-docker
      owner: root
      group: root
      mode: 0755     
  - name: Write docker-compose.yaml
    template:
      src: docker-compose.yaml.j2
      dest: /etc/registry-docker/docker-compose.yaml
      owner: root
      group: root
      mode: 644

Then also move the docker-compose file from roles/registry/files/registry-docker/docker-compose.yaml to roles/registry/templates/docker-compose.yaml.j2.

Okay, now it's a different set of tests failing there.
This is broken for sure and I have no idea why.

Something is acting weird when testing the failover with TCP.
If the first syslog server in the list is disabled, rsyslog always tries to connect to it during (action.resumeRetryCount * action.resumeInterval) seconds for each bulk of messages, then it gives up and sends the messages to the second server.

when forward all log is enabled, it also sends a lot of error messages related to the failover:
Mar  4 08:27:58 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]
Mar  4 08:28:00 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]
Mar  4 08:28:02 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]
Mar  4 08:28:04 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]
Mar  4 08:28:06 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]
Mar  4 08:28:08 amphora-f57aa693-de88-4b79-8897-ee58eb4dc853 rsyslogd[2970]: cannot connect to 192.168.0.198:10514: Connection refused [v8.2102.0-7.el8 try https://www.rsyslog.com/e/2027 ]

Using:

[amphora_agent]
log_retry_count = 0
log_retry_interval = 1800

fixes the behavior I observed.
Maybe we should recommend setting these parameters when using TCP protocol for syslog.
I think it can be addressed in a followup commit

Yes, I see those messages too. I don't think that this is a weird behavior though. RSyslog will retry retry_count time till it sets the first action to suspended state. Then, eventually, Rsyslog will use the second server. I didn't realize however that it happens for each bulk of messages.

I don't think we should filter out those "Connection refused" messages as they could be useful for debugging. However, with multiple servers retry_count should be  very low, probably 1. I could adjust the template so that 

action.resumeRetryCount="{{ retry_count }}"
action.resumeInterval="{{ retry_interval }}"

only gets used if there is only one log host. Would that be okay?

ovb repos will go to another job:
- opendev.org/openstack-virtual-baremetal

- opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade

```
- tripleo-ci-base-common-required-projects
  - tripleo-ci-base-common-ovb-projects

- tripleo-ci-base-common-required-projects
  - tripleo-ci-base-common-upgrade-projects
```

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I think my brain have after a while distorted what I was reading on https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/system-config/latest/zuul.html#secrets about secrets. On the other side we should still have something like key exhaustion (https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/system-config/latest/zuul.html#secrets) and similar stuff (yes, we rotate secret, but not the key used to encrypt the secret). I am not against of having some secrets encrypted by Zuul, but clearly rotating this data often without rotating the private key is like a red flag for any security person.

On the other side, as you mentioned, we also have people accessing bridge and using it further for ops reasons (and believe we do this daily). Moving secrets to Zuul is clearly going to make this harder, since secrets can not be fetched on the bridge. In our approach playbooks are being executed on the bridge exactly like before (both by Zuul and manually). It's just that the secrets are being fetched by Ansible from Vault directly (where absolutely necessary). Where it is not necessary we modify system deployments so that they are able to fetch secrets they require for work directly from Vault (i.e. Grafana deployment fetches itself DB password from Vault).

Last, but not least, is the issue with rotation itself, that mostly that need to be a synchronous process. If you rotate DB password and update it in Git i.e. Grafana (as from example above) is not capable to access DB anymore until change is reviewed/merged/deployed - we know from practice it takes days rather then minutes. Not every secret is so complex, but it is very often the case (especially rotating password for OpenStack user i.e. nodepool is using).

Honestly speaking our approach is not really resolving problem with bridge bootstrapping, and instead is making it even more challenging (depends from which angle you look). But at least now we are sure that from the security point of view we are moving to the safe side (having rotation/audit/least_required_privilege addressed).

My biggest concern with Zuul is that one you (accidentally or not, corruption) loose Zuul (encryption keys, or maybe even completely) - you are completely screwed. You can not recover even Zuul itself without manual steps on the bridge, but it most likely lacks required secrets. To avoid this you will not put all secrets into Zuul. But that, on the other side, just increases amount of different approaches used.

We have actually submitted talk for Summit to describe how we are doing this. If there is interest we can present this also in a smaller round for infra folks beforehand.
Sure. Things just start as a spec and it is exactly time to raise points before they get more complex.

in most cases security regulations of companies are requiring that any type of secret is being periodically rotated. Storing them in Zuul is making that both hard and reduces secret safety with each iteration (as also written in Zuul docs if I read them correctly). We will not go this way. Instead we created analog sys-config project in the private repository and merge their states on the bridge. In addition private repo is also not having secrets directly, but knows where to get them from (Hashi Vault in our case). With this secrets themselves are stored in Vaul where they can be easily rotated, and jobs/playbooks are knowing how to get secrets (actually we rely mostly on lookup plugins not even ti take care of that).
This is correct that bootstraping step need to be rethought, but simply puting secrets as zuul secrets is not proper from security pov.

> Moving secrets to Zuul is clearly going to make this harder, since secrets can not be fetched on the bridge.

> My biggest concern with Zuul is that one you (accidentally or not, corruption) loose Zuul (encryption keys, or maybe even completely) - you are completely screwed. You can not recover even Zuul itself without manual steps on the bridge, but it most likely lacks required secrets.

Note that this proposal is only suggesting to write the secrets kept in Zuul secret definitions to the bastion host for ansible to consume.  This is ~ equivalent to the current situation where humans write the secrets to the bastion host (except of course for the obvious caveat that Zuul has now has an encrypted copy at rest, as opposed to it being essentially discarded from the human's brain by assuming they can't remember it 😊.  But in terms of being able to manually run ansible on the bastion host, or recover if Zuul is lost, I believe we're in exactly the same situation.

You have made me think though -- is it a better idea to just encrypt the value with a public key, with the private portion kept on the bastion host, and then write that out with a Zuul job (that has access to the private key on the bastion host).  

This is an option because the bastion host is static, but still allows anyone to commit a key to the repository.

We're already keeping the secrets on the bastion host, so having the private key there doesn't seem any different; if you can access the key you can access the secrets anyway.

Thanks, I'm definitely interested in iterating on any ideas that we can come up with.

I agree on the need for rotation; I'm not sure it's particularly easier or harder than any other way to rotate.  Ultimately you just have to run a little script and propose a change with this model.

I'm not sure that rotating and re-encrypting a zuul value makes it any less secure. Can you clarify this a bit more?  I will admit that this creates a side-channel where you give away some information by committing a change that tells everyone the key was just rotated, but I'm not aware it would weaken the secret value as such.

The back-end system on the bastion/bridge we can consider opaque I guess (our bastion has something similar to get keys into place from repos for ansible to read).  The general point is that this system is managed by selected operators who need explicit permission to add/remove/rotate secrets.

We are trying to live an open-infrastructure model, where we would ideally like non-privileged users to be able to manage production systems.  (Sometimes, when things have really gone wrong, you need to log in.  But we want to make this the absolute exception, as much as possible.)

I've just put up for review some related work that will allow production deployment logs to be viewed by people who have a GPG key committed to the system-config repo [1].  That is in a similar orbit of allowing anyone with interest to help manage the systems.

So this does have to be filtered though a lens of trying to achieve these goals. This obviously isn't every project's goal, but it is ours 😊

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bridge-encrypt-logs

This _create_branch() method and the _delete_branch() method below seem to only operate on a github api level and not a git repo level. There are no objects with shas created from what I can tell which is part of the reason why this test fails as is.

The other reason (which may be related to the above issue) is that repo_state is empty when merging:

> 2022-02-17 07:01:31,440 zuul.MergeClient                 DEBUG    [e: 548e182f1ea3466f9cef6d02369c2aa3] Submitting job 4bf09d50d04a4626b8680266042770e7 with data {'items': [{'project': 'github/project2', 'connection': 'github', 'merge_mode': 2, 'ref': 'refs/pull/1/head', 'branch': 'master', 'buildset_uuid': '23fe2bb1ffa247ba911b3261025cd081', 'number': 1, 'patchset': 'c18b757348272bb5b4d73ddf60b53a598fb03d83', 'oldrev': None, 'newrev': None}, {'project': 'gerrit/project1', 'connection': 'gerrit', 'merge_mode': 2, 'ref': 'refs/changes/01/1/1', 'branch': 'master', 'buildset_uuid': '937f5e64e0664cae9cca7c888b42d9ec', 'number': '1', 'patchset': '1', 'oldrev': None, 'newrev': None}], 'files': ['zuul.yaml', '.zuul.yaml'], 'dirs': ['zuul.d', '.zuul.d'], 'repo_state': None, 'branches': None}

The repo_state not being none is how we tripped this before. We need that to contain the branch that is being deleted so that it tries to configure that branch on the repo to the sha that is no longer valid.

This is a good insight, and I've used create_branch() and that actually creates the branch.

I had the thought that deleting the branch isn't enough, because the object could still be there.  So I added a purge_branch that forces cleanup.  But it's still not being referenced as I thought it would.

I've split it into https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/829842 with related info in the CL; if there's interest in collaborating we can look at it there but so far I'm lost on how to get the merger into this path.

I suspect that ZuulTestCase's create_branch() and delete_branch() may impart the necessary repository state for this. I'm not sure if that will impact the repo_state value that is passed to the merger though. It may if it depends on the branches actually existing in the repository and not just in the API.

cinder/volume/drivers/hitachi/hbsd_rest..message: These should have descriptions since they will appear in sample configs, etc.

I think your usage of these is going to make this code difficult to maintain.  Usually these ALL_CAPS variables are used like constants, but in this file, these are used to provide default values to the config options, and then init_timer_values() re-sets their values based on the config option, and then these are used in the code.  If someone uses one of these before init_timer_values() is called, you will get a bug (using an incorrect timeout value) that will be difficult to trace.

Since init_timer_values() is being called in HBDREST.__init__(), it's unlikely this will happen, but as this code is maintained and refactored, you never know.  This issue doesn't seem to have bothered any other reviewers, so I won't hold this patch up over it, but you might want to consider a follow-up refactoring.

I think it's possible to report a start to sql without reporting a start to the code review system if there are no "start" reporters in the pipeline (so "reported_start" means "there are jobs and a start reporter").  So if we leave this as is, we may not report end to sql in the case there are jobs but no start reporter.

I think that checking reported_start in reportDequeue is still an okay solution and handles that case.

I'm not sure we can or want to make the conditions the same though, since one of them depends on whether there's a start reporter.

We could move sql.reportBuildsetStart to _processOneItem; that might make things a little more clear, but I don't think it really changes anything.  We'd still have to do 3/4 checks before doing that, and then one more check for whether there are start reporters before reporting to code review.
This both reports and updates the sql db.  Maybe we should put the reported_start check inside reportDequeue so that we still close out the sql entry?

I just checked and we sql.reportBuildsetStart only if item.job_graph.jobs > 0. Maybe we should change the condition to that so those are the same? Reading the code I think we currently may even close out non-existent sql entries since we open them conditionally and close them unconditionally.
